Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Kinematics, Microphysics and Dynamics of Long-fetch Lake-effect Systems in Ontario Winter Lake-effect Systems (OWLeS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is one key segment of a larger effort centered on the Ontario Winter (OW) Lake-effect Systems (LeS) field project, to be conducted December 2013-January 2014. OWLeS will focus on two complementary lines of research, each tracing to a preferred wind regime over the U.S. Great lakes region and corresponding distinct mesoscale mode of winter storm organization. Activities led by this group will focus on so-called "long-fetch" storm events, for which low-level winds are aligned approximately parallel to Lake Ontario's long axis. Observational assets to be employed during OWLeS include the University of Wyoming King Air instrumented aircraft, the CSWR Doppler on Wheels (DOW) mobile radars, multiple mobile rawinsounding systems, the Millersville University Profiling System, the UAH Mobile Integrated Profiling System, and a variety of other deployable surface measurement systems. These researchers contend that predictions of the amounts and inland extent of LeS snowfall remain poor, due in part to fine-scale variations in upwind planetary boundary layer structure and poor representation of cloud microphysical, dynamical, and surface processes. To address these shortcomings, the intellectual merits of this research will derive from improved understanding of: 1) How long-fetch LeS intensify and evolve downwind of the lake, where prolonged heavy snowfall rates are particularly impactful; 2) how cloud and dynamical processes may contribute to cloud electrification and to lightning, as occasionally observed in long-fetch LeS heavy precipitation cells; and 3) how dual-polarimetric (and in select regions, dual-Doppler) radar measurements at X- and S-band wavelengths as utilized by mobile-DOW and operational National Weather Service WSR-88D radars, respectively, may reveal detailed precipitation processes in LeS. Through detailed comparisons with in-situ aircraft measurements, evaluations dual-polarimetric particle identification and quantitative precipitation estimate (QPE) algorithms will extend the utility of remote-sensing observations in this unique cool-season environment.

Broader impacts will include experience infield campaign planning, hands-on data collection and data analysis for a notably large number of undergraduate as well as graduate students. A desirable mix of junior and senior principal investigators will facilitate exchange of established and complex project design and observing methodologies, and foster improved field observing techniques tailored to severe winter weather conditions. Outreach efforts will extend to K-12 students and college students enrolled at nearby institutes of higher learning. Given the significant impacts of lake effect snowfall on public safety and economic activity along the populous shores of the U.S. Great Lakes, improved understanding of lake-effect systems should foster refined models and forecasting techniques that will address a longer-term societal need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lake-effect snowstorms can result in localized snowfall accumulations up to several feet within only a few days. Each fall and winter season, cities such as Grand Rapids, Michigan, and Buffalo and Syracuse, New York, experience heavy lake-effect snows. These storms produce significant impacts in affected regions, including halting air travel, shutting down highways, and closing schools, government offices, and businesses. The often highly-localized nature of lake-effect snow storms can make prediction particularly difficult, since even some of the heaviest bands can only be tens of miles wide and total snow accumulations can vary by as much as a few feet within only a few miles.

 

The research conducted under this NSF grant increased our understanding of lake-effect storms. During the winter of 2013-14, an armada of scientific instrumentation, including mobile Doppler radars, instrumented vehicles, and portable weather stations, was deployed to a region of Upstate New York downwind of Lake Ontario that frequently experiences heavy lake-effect snowstorms. During the field phase of this project, we gathered data on 24 different lake-effect snow events of varying morphologies, including intense single-band events that often produce crippling snowfall totals in localized areas and multiple band events that produce lesser snowfall amounts but spread over larger areas. Six undergraduate students, one graduate student, and one faculty member from the University of Illinois Department of Atmospheric Sciences joined dozens of other scientists and students from several other Universities and research labs to collect this dataset. The students received training on how to forecast lake-effect snow, operate mobile Doppler radars, and gather and download data from mobile instruments.

 

The subsequent data analysis performed under this grant increased our understanding of lake-effect snowstorms. Several strings of vortices, between 1-3 km in diameter, were detected moving along wind shifts within the lake-effect bands. The strongest of these vortices may be as strong as a weak (EF-0) tornado. The lake-effect bands were stronger and the vortices were more prevalent in regimes of large-scale upward motion, which resulted in more favorable conditions for lake-effect snow formation. Conversely, in regimes of large-scale downward motion, the bands were generally weaker and less organized. In a stronger band, currents of rising air are faster, and greater convergence and a sharper wind shift exist beneath these rising air currents. Analyses of Doppler radar data collected during multiple lake-effect events revealed that the intra-band wind shift is likely key to the development of these vortices. For the first time, our analyses revealed that these vortices likely form owing to the release of a shearing instability along this wind shift, and this conclusion was substantiated by an atmospheric model simulation.

 

Analyses of airborne Doppler radar data collected within many different lake-effect bands reveals that several distinct regimes of convection are present within the bands, including strong and deep surface-based convection over water, weak, shallow surface-based convection over land (particularly during the daytime), waves aloft, and small generating cells near the top of the clouds. The generating cells were not found to be ubiquitous, although a relationship between the presence of generating cells and band intensity, time of day, or whether the band was over land or water could not be determined.

 

Data collected by weather balloon-borne instruments was quality controlled to determine if the instrument iced up during ascent through the snow bands. We determined that only 10% of the instruments iced up during ascent and that incidences of ice up appear to be more common at warmer temperatures that are still cold enough to support snow. This procedure will prove beneficial to future researchers analyzing this dataset.

 

Research supported by this grant resulted in education, training, and professional development of several students. One graduate student has already completed his master’s degree and has transitioned into a Ph.D. program. His thesis resulted in a peer-reviewed scientific publication in a leading American Meteorological Society journal. Two other graduate students are currently working on their master’s degrees and have been funded by this grant. This grant supported a total of eight undergraduate students, seven of whom completed their capstone undergraduate research course by analyzing data collected during this project; six of these students went on to graduate school. Additionally, this grant supported fourteen presentations at national conferences and numerous other presentations at regional or university-sponsored conferences. Data collected during this project is regularly featured in undergraduate and graduate-level atmospheric sciences classes at the University of Illinois and the large dataset collected during this project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students for years to come.
